content:
Terrorists, Nude Beaches, and Anarchist Plots

Amy's Interests

Name: Amy Dawson
E-mail: easu372
Major: Political Science, with an emphasis on International Relations

Three neat Web finds:

  1. UNABOM Press Release: UNABOM is an organization I started in response to the F.B.I.'s poor record of successfully pursuing terrorists; I'm undercover here at UCI working on our latest lead. This is highly confidential information; betray me at your peril.
  2. Congressional e-mail addresses: This is a good way to monitor the activities of subversive Congresspersons: send them treasonous e-mail and see if they bite. Could be particularly useful regarding the Speaker; you know what they say about those in sheep's clothing...
  3. Society and Culture: Alternative: Watch out for this radical hotbed of troublemaking commies; their psudo-intellectual discourse maligns the likes of Ollie and the N.R.A., not to mention their simply unconscionable Newtbashing.

Questions I can now answer
  • Where can one find a good, clothing optional beach away from home?
  • How can one get a passeport to a country that doesn't exist, and subsequently create the promised land?
  • What exhibits are now on display, and what resources are currently available, at the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris?
  • What is HTML, and where can I learn how to create an HTML document?
  • What do the South Georgia and Sandwich Islands have in common with Montserrat? (Formerly "where to get Tarot and I Ching readings on line?")

  • Where can one find a good, clothing optional beach away from home?

     Naturists are always in search of new, exciting locales where they can bask in the buff; especially when travelling. If you get tired of your favorite bare beach, or find yourself on the road without your bikini/trunks, you can always try one of our recommended sunspots; bring plenty of lotion! We have listings in Florida, Texas, (a great little site called Hippie Hollow), California, and Minnesota, to name a few. You can also enjoy life without tanlines in Europe, particularily in Italy and France. International relations are often much advanced in these political arenas.

    Return to list of questions.

  • How can one get a passeport from a country that doesn't exist, and subsequently help create the promised land?

    Any good political scientist is interested in the history and structure of myriad nations; some countries are constantly being overthrown and "recreated," others remain relatively stable, and still others fall somewhere in between. Rarely does the opportunity arise to chronicle the dvelopement of an entirely new country, from its nascent ideological inception to its physical creation and developement. The Atlantis Project has come up with plans to literally build a new island, to be called Oceania. You can obtain information on Oceania's Constitution and laws, as well as its conceptual founders and information on obtaining a passeport, by investigating The Atlantis Project. An interesting prospect for the fringe element. Query: can we send people there involuntarily? (ahem!)

    Return to list of questions.

  • What exhibits are now on display, and what resources are currently available, at the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris?

     One current exhibit electronically recreates the voice of one of the most renouned castratti, Carlo Broschi, also known as Farinelli . He lived from 1705-1782, so obviously there is no extant recording of his voice. To enhance a film dedicated to Farinelli by Gerard Corbiau, an organization called Ircam engineered a voice that is beyond the scope of current performers. En francais. One can also get information (in French or in English) on HIV and AIDS, including counselling and support, free and anonymous testing centers, health organizations, and more from the Pompidou Center. If it weren't for Steve Franklin's hotlist, I don't know that I would ever have come across this information. Thank goodness for this class!

    Return to list of questions.

  • What is HTML, and where can I learn how to create an HTML document ?

     Ahhhh, the excitement of HTML. HTML, or hypertext markup language provides structure to documents on the World Wide Web. HTML uses a series of codes to transmit data, which are in turn translated by a client (such as Mosaic, Lynx, or Viola, for example) into recognizable screen formats. The most valuable aspect of HTML lies in its inherently interactive nature; one can "click" on highlighted text with the aid of a favorite rodent, connecting to to new links, maps, images, headings, etc. in order to continue a certain search path or to veer onto another search course. HTML is still inferior to most desktop publishing programs, with constraints on font selection and graphics placement, and many limitations on relatively simple functions. For a good introduction to HTML, try the Beginners Guide to HTML, which covers the basic elements of creating an HTML document. Next you may want to reference Composing Good HTML, which can help with troubleshooting and improper use of various commands.

    Return to list of questions.

  • What do the South Georgia and Sandwich Islands have in common with Montserrat? Formerly "Where can I get my daily Tarot and I Ching readings on line?"

    South Georgia, the South Sandwich Islands, and Montserrat are all islands administered by the U.K. Montserrat is located in the Carribean, about 400 miles southeast of Puerto Rico, while the South Georgian and Sandwich islands nestle in near Argentina. Argentina claims that the nearby islands belong to them, but Brittain maintains control. Montserrat has an indigenous population of about 12,701, while South Georgia is populated only by the folks in a small military garrison; the South Sandwich islands are uninhabited. All are subject to volcanic activity, all count fishing as an important natural resource, and all are under Chief of State Queen Elizabeth II.

    Return to list of questions.

Submitted January 30, 1995 for ICS 1C
